Award.AwardTitle: Compact wave function methods for chemical systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division is supporting Dr. Alan Aspuru-Guzik of Harvard University to develop an efficient and accurate method to study the electronic structure of molecules and solids that are difficult to study by existing approaches. The Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering programs in Chemistry and Physics, as well the CISE/ACI CIF21 Venture Fund for Software Reuse will contribute to the award. The exact quantum mechanical description of the electronic structure of atoms, molecules and solids is computationally intractable. Accurate computational descriptions that can be carried out with current computers for systems of practically relevant sizes remains a challenge. If available, accurate descriptions promise a transformative acceleration in the cycle of materials design. The proposed work advances a new idea for the compact representation of the wave functions of atoms, molecules and materials by borrowing ideas of the field of signal processing. The Aspuru-Guzik group is working to optimize the computer code, and then to release it both as open source and incorporated in popular quantum chemistry computer packages. The ideas and software developed in this project will be incorporated into a massive open online course (MOOC), entitled " The Quantum World", that Aspuru-Guzik is developing under the HarvardX platform.


A technique borrowed from the field of signal processing, matching pursuit, is combined with a non-orthogonal orbital expansion. Preliminary results show that the method is competitive with the state-of-the-art methods but still requires considerable software development and theoretical extension. The main objective of the current project is to advance the proposed method, namely the non-orthogonal multicomponent adaptive greedy iterative compression (NOMAGIC). NOMAGIC already has shown excellent wave function compression of the order of tens of determinants for obtaining chemically accurate solutions. Aspuru-Guzik and coworkers are developing the NOMAGIC method as a black box method to be incorporated with several electronic structure packages. The researchers are developing methods for excited state simulation as well as to extend the ansatz considered by the approach to tensor networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One challenge of quantum chemistry methods is the tradeoff between accuracy and computational scaling. In general, we could get better results with a wave function represented by a large number of parameters, since they confer certain flexibility to depict the electronic structure of a molecule. However, computational scaling makes the computations intractable in most of the molecular systems up to a certain number of parameters.

Within the project, we have developed and released an open-source quantum chemistry software package DiffiQult. With this tool, we are capable of optimizing the one-particle basis functions, which defines the parameters of the wavefunctions of most electronic structure methods. We tested our approach by improving the electronic energy of some molecular systems with the Hartree-Fock method since it is the starting point of several electronic structure methods. Since the standard basis sets were optimized for atoms, we could improve them specifically for each molecule. With this approach, after partial and full optimization of all possible parameters, we found results similar to those obtained using a standard larger basis set optimized. Therefore, we can generate small molecular tailored basis functions with our implementation.

Parallelly, we demonstrated an application of automatic differentiation (AD) in quantum chemistry. Derivatives play an important role in the optimization methods, as well in some molecular properties. Since it is challenging to obtain the analytical expression and implementation of derivatives in quantum chemistry, we explored AD techniques in our implementation.

In our project, we carefully reviewed and discussed all the mathematical functions that a Hartree-Fock method contains and the current capabilities of AD libraries, and we implemented DiffiQult accordingly. Our implementation is written in plain Python language, capable of use AD tools to obtain derivatives of any independent variable. We hope this discussion could help future applications since the Hartree-Fock algorithm shares most of the complex mathematical functions of other methods. In this form, we can obtain derivatives with respect to any parameter without explicitly derivate or code any analytical gradients. 

We have shared our results in a manuscript (ACS Centr. Sci. 4 (2018) 559), and the code and documentation have been released (https://github.com/aspuru-guzik-group/DiffiQult, https://aspuru-guzik-group.github.io/DiffiQult/).

Finally, the optimized basis functions obtained by DiffiQult can be used as a starting point for more accurate calculations such as applications in quantum computing or electron correlatation methods, where are often limited by the number of basis functions. For instance, the number of basis functions is directly related to the number of Qubits in a quantum computer which is limited by current hardware. We have implemented an application program interface to use the results easily from DiffiQult in PySCF. PySCF is an electronic structure software package that computes post-Hartree-Fock methods and contains an interface with OpenFermion, a quantum computer simulator. Therefore, Diffiqult is also able to provide an improved minimal one particle basis sets quantum computer emulator and post-Hartree-Fock methods.
